title-group.article-title: Synthesis and characterization of high-quality polyaniline nanofibres

article-meta.aff: 1Faculty of Mechanical Engineering, Universiti Teknologi Malaysia, Johor Bahru, Malaysia
2Faculty of Bioscience and Bioengineering, Universiti Teknologi Malaysia, Johor Bahru, Malaysia
3Faculty of Chemical Engineering, Universiti Teknologi Malaysia, Johor Bahru, Malaysia

author-notes.corresp: Esah Hamzah, Faculty of Mechanical Engineering, Universiti Teknologi Malaysia, Johor Bahru 81310, Malaysia. Email: esah@fkm.utm.my

abstract.p: This article aims to study the synthesis of high-quality polyaniline (PANI) nanofibres through simple interfacial polymerization method in the presence of different acids. Ammonium persulphate, chloroform and different acids were used as oxidant, organic solvent and dopant, respectively. Field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM), Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) and X-ray diffraction (XRD) techniques were used to characterize the PANI nanofibres. FESEM results show different morphologies of PANI particles were produced from the various acid mixtures. FT-IR and XRD results confirmed the formation of PANI particles. XRD results show that PANI nanofibre is partially in crystalline nature.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Conductive polymers are one of the most important and attractive materials in the world, due to their good electrical, electrochemical and optical properties. In the year 2000, Shirakawa et al acquired the Nobel Prize in chemistry for the discovery and progress of conductive polymers. 1 Conductive polymers have been used in various applications such as sensors, 2 solar cells, 3 catalysts 4 and anticorrosive coatings. 5 –7 Among conductive polymers, polyaniline (PANI) has gained more attention because of its unique properties such as low cost monomer, ease of synthesis, good redox properties and high environmental stability. 8 –10 Generally, there are two main methods to synthesis PANI: (a) electrochemical and (b) chemical methods. Electrochemical methods are used to directly synthesize PANI on the substrate surfaces, 11 and chemical methods are used for the production of PANI in large quantities. 12 In conventional chemical methods, the aniline monomer is polymerized using an oxidant agent in the presence of acidic dopants. The synthesized PANI has granular morphology. It has been found that granular PANI has some limitations such as poor processability and low solubility in conventional solvents. In contrast, due to their high surface area PANI nanofibres have excellent processability and good solubility in common solvents. Various methods have been developed for the synthesis of PANI nanofibres including hard templates, 13 soft template, 14 interfacial polymerization, 15 seeding polymerization, 16 electrospinning 17 and ultrasonic irradiation. 18 Despite all methods are able to synthesize PANI nanofibres, there is still a need for a simple and template-free method to synthesize pure, uniform and high-quality PANI nanofibres in large scale. Among these methods, interfacial polymerization has gained more attention due to the ease of synthesis and high-quality production of nanofibres in large quantities. 15 In this article, a simple interfacial polymerization method that produced PANI nanofibre is reported. The influence of acidic dopant type on the morphology and quality of PANI nanofibres was investigated and also reported. Comparison was made between PANI nanofibres and granular PANI in terms of crystallinity and dissolubility in water. Based on the literature study, not many researchers reported on the synthesis and production of high-quality polyanaline nanofibre. Thus, there has been a need to investigate further on the synthesis of high-quality PANI nanofibres.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: Aniline monomer, ammonium persulphate, chloroform, hydrochloric acid, sulphuric acid, boric acid, nitric acid and oxalic acid were purchased from Aldrich Company (Sigma-Aldrich, Selangor, Malaysia) and are used as received.

sec.title: Synthesis method
sec.p: In the conventional synthesis method, polymerization was carried out by the chemical oxidation of aniline in the presence of hydrochloric acid and ammonium persulfate as dopant and oxidant, respectively. 4 mmol of Aniline was well dissolved in 20 mL of 1 M HCl. Then, 20 mL of 1 M Ammonium persulfate solution was added to the aniline solution during 2 h. The new solution was well stirred for 2 h. Then, the green dark product was washed with distilled water and acetone repeatedly. Finally, the product was dried at room temperature for 48 h.

Interfacial polymerization method was carried out by preparing two separate solutions; in the first solution, 4 mmol ammonium persulphate was dissolved in 20 ml of acid (1 M) solution and stirred for about 1 h. In the second solution, 4 mmol aniline monomer was added to 20 ml chloroform and was also stirred for 1 h. Then, the first solution was poured into the second solution to create an immiscible organic/aqueous biphasic system. Replicate experiments were done in order to confirm the effect of different acids on the morphology of PANI particles.

sec.title: Characterization
sec.p: The morphology of the samples was characterized by the field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM, Zeiss-LEO Model 1530 (Carl Zeiss Sdn. Bhd, Malaysia)). Molecular structures of PANI were characterized using Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR; VERTEX70 infrared spectrometer (Perkin Elmer, Selangor, Malaysia) (using pellets with KBr)). The crystallinity of samples were measured using X-ray Diffraction (XRD; Ultima III x-ray diffractometer (Bruker, Selangor, Malaysia) using Cu Kα radiation)

sec.title: Synthesis of PANI nanofibre
sec.p: Interfacial polymerization is known as a common method to produce large quantities of PANI nanofibres. The polymerization process takes place at the interface of two immiscible solutions: water and organic solutions. After a short induction time, the dark green products are appeared at the interface of solutions, indicates the formation of PANI (Figure 1(b)). By the time, the green dark products move to the water based solution (Figure 1(c), (d)) and finally fulfil the entire water solution (Figure 1(e)). The color of organic based solution became darker by the time. After several hours the polymerization process was completed and green dark PANI could be collected for filtration process. 15

caption.p: Interfacial polymerization of polyaniline nanofibre in sulphuric acid at (a) 5 s, (b) 20 s, (c) 1 min, (d) 5 min, (e) 1 h.

sec.p: In this study, four acids, sulphuric, nitric, oxalic and boric acid, with different strength were used to study their influence on the morphology and quality of synthesized PANI nanofibres. Table 1 summarizes the strength of the acids. Acids with Ka values >1 such as sulphuric acid and nitric acid are listed as strong acids. Acids with Ka < 1 such as oxalic acid and boric acid are considered as weak acids. Figure 2 shows the FESEM image of PANI nanofibres in the presence of different acids.

caption.p: Polyaniline nanofibres synthesized by interfacial polymerization method in the presence of (a) boric acid, (b) oxalic acid, (c) nitric acid, (d) sulphuric acid.

sec.p: It was found that certain acids with different strengths affect the morphology, uniformity and quality of PANI. Generally, the formation of PANI nanofibres is related to the linear nature of PANI chains. 15 It has been found that even in conventional methods, polyaniline nanofibers are initially formed. However, they are exposed to further growth and finally, the granular PANI particles are formed (Figure 3).

caption.p: Field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) image of (a) granular polyaniline synthesized by conventional method (b) polyaniline nanofibre synthesized by interfacial polymerization method.

sec.p: In interfacial polymerization, nanofibers are formed initially at the interface (Figure 1(b)) and then move to the upper water layer (Figure 1(d)). In consequence, the nanofibers are not subject to further polymerization. Thus, the significant key to fabricate nanofibres in interfacial polymerization method is to suppress the secondary growth. 19,20 As shown in Figure 2(a) and (b), when the weak acid such as boric or oxalic acid was used, the products are mixtures of particles and fibres. However as shown in Figure 2(c) and (d), the PANI nanofibres are uniquely uniform when sulphuric or nitric acid was used. PANI obtained in HNO3 and H2SO4 system possessed nano fibrous morphology with good uniformity. It has been found that the acid with more strength could result in uniform PANI nanofibers. The uniformity of PANI nanofibre in the presence of strong acids could be explained as follows: As described in Figure 4, when aniline is dissolved in the strong acids such as HNO3 and H2SO4, high fraction of aniline cations are generated. The cations are of high propagation rate and within a short time were directly polymerized to PANI nanofibre, thus there is insufficient time for nanofibres to further polymerize. Therefore, uniform polyaniline nanofibers are synthesized in presence of strong acids. Moreover, in a strong acid, the PANI molecular chain grew one dimensional along the central line. During the polymerization process, the solubility of PANI decreased and large amount of nanofibers were precipitated in the solution. 21 Based on the above theory, in the HNO3 and H2SO4 system, due to their strong oxidation capability, a greater number of aniline oligomers appeared in a short time. This leads to a greater number of ionized aniline oligomers and resulted in the generation of more uniform nanofibres. Furthermore, in the H2SO4 system, it was beneficial for the high rate of ionization (aniline oligomers) and chain growth since excellent nanofibres could be obtained. 21,22 As shown in Figure 5(a), in the presence of weak acids, the initial nanofibres formed become the “nucleation” centers for further polymerization and finally grow into irregularly shaped granular particles (heterogeneous nucleation). However, as shown in Figure 5(b), in the presence of strong acids, the initial PANI nanofibres are not subjected to secondary growth, therefore uniform PANI nanofibre could be synthesized (homogenous nucleation). Thus, the function of acidity leads to suppression of the secondary growth and formation of high-quality and uniform nanofibres.

caption.p: Aniline cation fraction versus pH: in lower pH (high acidity) more fraction of cation are generated which directly polymerized to nanofibre.23
Schematic of (a) heterogeneous nucleation and (b) homogenous nucleation.24

sec.title: FTIR
sec.p: Figure 6 shows the FTIR spectra of doped granular PANI and doped-PANI nanofibers. The main peaks at around 1,580 and 1,490 cm−1 can be associated with C=N and C=C stretching vibrations of quinone and benzene rings, respectively. The peaks at around 1,300 and 1,240 cm−1 attributed to the C-N stretching mode. The peak at around 1,120 cm−1 is due to quinonoid unit of doped PANI. The peak at around 800 cm−1 is attributed to the out-of-plane bending of C-H. These related peaks confirm the formation of PANI. The FTIR results confirm that acid-doped PANI is synthesized by interfacial polymerization method.

caption.p: The FTIR spectra of the PANI. (a) Granular PANI, (b) H2SO4-PANI; (c) HNO3-PANI.

sec.title: XRD analysis
sec.p: Figure 7 shows the XRD pattern of PANI nanofibre prepared by interfacial polymerization method. From XRD results, the crystallinity of products could be studied. The crystallinity and orientation of conducting polymers are very important, because more highly crystalline systems can display a metallic behavior and are more useful in different applications such as anticorrosive coatings. As shown in Figure 7, for PANI nanofiber, three sharp peaks centered at around 2θ = 6°,20° and 26°, show that PANI nanofiber is partially in crystalline nature. The peak at 2θ = 6° is assigned as the periodicity distance between the dopant and N atom on adjacent main chains while the later two sharp bands are ascribed to the periodicity parallel and perpendicular to the polymer chains of PANI, respectively. Therefore, PANI nanofibre is partially in crystalline nature and it is useful in different applications.

caption.p: X-ray diffraction pattern of PANI nanofibre. PANI: polyaniline.

sec.title: Dissolubility of PANI nanofibre
sec.p: The dissolubility of PANI in conventional solvents is another important issue, which could be useful in different application such as anticorrosive coatings. It has been found that the more soluble PANI in solvent result in the formation of a uniform and compact anticorrosive layer. 22 As shown in Figure 8(a), in the case of PANI nanofibre a blackish green color solution was formed with no settlement in water. Thus, PANI nanofibre synthesized by interfacial polymerization method exhibit excellent solubility in distilled water due to its uniform nanofibrillar morphology. However, the granular PANI does not show a good dissolubility in water due to its micro-size morphology, and it will precipitate with time.

caption.p: Dissolubility of (a) PANI nanofibre; (b) PANI granular in distilled water after 24 h. PANI: polyaniline.

list-item.p: Interfacial polymerization of aniline in the presence of acids with different strengths was successfully done.
FESEM results show that the high-quality and uniform PANI nanofibres could be obtained in the presence of strong acids such as sulphuric and nitric acids.
FT-IR results confirm the successful formation of PANI particles in the presence of different acids.
XRD results showed that PANI nanofibres obtained in presence of strong acid (sulphuric acid) are partially in crystalline nature.
PANI nanofibers obtained in presence of strong acids (nitric and sulphuric acid) have excellent dissolubility in water. However, the granular PANI has poor dissolubility in water.
